content: Thunderbird retains the last password that you used. If your account is now refusing it, that indicates the password is no longer valid. You can view or edit the password at settings>privacy&security, click savedpasswords and then showpasswords and can then view or change. Otherwise, you may need to contact Frontier for a new password.

content:
No user in their right mind should be giving their Google password to Thunderbird.

Gmail is Google. How do you think you get to your Gmail messages via Thunderbird without providing your Google account password?

If you use OAuth2 authentication with Thunderbird for your Gmail account (which you should use), you'd get exactly the kind of login prompt you describe. This is a Thunderbird window, and it's not related to any web browser at all. Neither is there any leakage from Chrome to Thunderbird. For this to work make sure you do have cookies enabled in Thunderbird.

content: Are you through venting? Are you ready to discuss your problem as an adult? Thunderbird is set to automatically apply updates to keep the application serving users properly. Most users appreciate that service. That setting may be turned off by users, and it is the user's responsibility to develop some basic awareness of what the app does. It is also possible to return to a prior setting when the update is found to not meet the user's preferences. I will also add here that support on this forum is from fellow users, not developers, not 'owner', not managers. Just users like you (only more polite and rational and prepared to handle life's problems as they occur). If you decide that you would like assistance, then please start over with your topic.

content:
Hi Just been testing your query on my system Windows OS Thunderbird version 128.3.3esr

When you say 'Appointments' - I'm assuming you are talking about 'Events'.

I'm only testing the 'Events' in the 'Home' default Thunderbird calendar.

In 'Settings > Calendar 'Default reminder setting for 'Events' set 'On' 'Default time a reminder is set before an Event' 1 day

In Calendar Click on 'New Event' Reminder says '1 day before'

In 'Settings > Calendar 'Default reminder setting for 'Events' set 'On' 'Default time a reminder is set before an Event' 1 hour

In Calendar Click on 'New Event' Reminder says '1 hour before'

In 'Settings > Calendar 'Default reminder setting for 'Events' set 'OFF' 'Default time a reminder is set before an Event' 1 hour

In Calendar Click on 'New Event' Reminder says 'No reminder'

As I change the settings, this will only effect any new events I create after the alterations in Settings. It does not effect any Events previously set up.

I'm not seeing a problem with default Reminder for Events.


However, I also have a gmail calendar.

Please note that when I select my gmail calendar and then click on 'New Event' In new Event window, it says: Reminder : 'Default Reminder'

This is not refering to the settings you have in Thunderbird. Google gmail account accessed via webmail using a browser. Default settings is 30 minutes before.

So not matter what I set up as default in Thunderbird, it will always use the google webmail default calendar setting meaning I either update gmail to say same as Thunderbird OR I have to alter the reminder each time I create an Event in the gmail calendar in Thunderbird.


So, is it possible you have Events in a calendar which is not the default Home Thunderbird calendar ? If yes, then it's defaulting to whatever you have on server - you need to update that by logging on to the relevant webmail account /calendar via a browser.

content:
It's not exactly very clear what you are are talking about.

Is this a gmail account or a microsoft account eg: outlook.com/live.com/hotmail.com/msn.com ?

re :asking for primary password . i have changed this

Changed what... did you logon to webmail account and modifiy a password for a mail account ? Then you want to update/edit the saved pasword in Thunderbird , but get stuck with a pop up asking for Primary Password- is that correct ?

'Primary Password' means a very specific thing in Thunderbird. It means you have previously set up a completely separate 'Primary Password' which is designed to stop all the people you allow to use your computer from accessing your saved mail account passwords. 'Primary Password' has nothing to do with mail account passwords and should never be the same as a mail account password. If you have managed to 'change' that 'primary password' then you shoud have no problems access the saved mail account passwords in oder to update them, but somehow I get the feeling we may not be on the same page.

In Settings > Privacy & Security' Scroll down to 'Passwords' section Is this checkbox selected 'Use Primary PAssword' ? If yes... When you click on 'Saved PAsswords' > 'Show Passwords', you will get asked for the 'Primary Password' in order to gain access. Enter the 'Primary Password' - do not get confused - this is not your mail account passwords.

If checkbox 'Use Primary PAssword' is not selected then you get a default password protection. eg: Windows OS get a 'winfowd security' pop up and it asks for the computer user account login password.

Is that 'Primary Password' checkbox selected or not ?

Have you logged on to webmail and modified a mail account password ? What server are you talking about ?

Microsoft have recently forced a load of changes and if this effects you then I'll need to provide a lot of information. Post this info: Help > Troubleshooting Information Scroll down to 'Mail and News Accounts' section.

copy all the data and paste it into this forum question. Then we will know what servers you use and can check you have correct server settings.

content: No email app is safe from crashes. Your best insurance is to backup frequently to prevent loss of data. Was this a POP or IMAP account? Keeping drafts online minimizes loss of the data, whereas a POP account is always subject to being lost in a crash. You might try looking in c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles to see if it is there in a lost profile. If there, it would be in the Mail\<accountname> folder or the Mail\Local Folders folder. Let me know if you need more info.
creator: davidsk

content: I am not a comcast guru, but if all settings are correct, you wouldn't need to post here. If you post screenshots of your incoming server pane and your SMTP server pane, someone here may have suggestions. Thanks
creator: davidsk

content:
Ok, I'll try several options, depending on your skill.

If you're comfortable with a bit of windows file explorer, here is the purest and best approach: Here is how i do it: - exit thunderbird on old PC - copy c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to external media (this assumes you use default installation) - on new PC, install thunderbird and exit - copy the backed-up thunderbird folder to c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming to overwrite the existing thunderbird folder - start thunderbird and everything will be there.

If you don't like that option, this may work: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' in left column and click 'open folder' - exit thunderbird - you are now in profile folder, press the back arrow one time to get outside the profile - now, copy that folder to external media - start thunderbird on new PC - click tools>import>import from another thunderbirdinstallation>Choose a profile folder and then locate and select the profile on the external media

If your profile is small, this is the least technical: - click tools>export and this will export to a zipped file - on new computer, click tools>import and follow above steps on tools>import>import from a file and then select the profile zip import

Let me know how it goes.
creator: davidsk
